awd_titl_txt: Topics in Analytic Number Theory and Additive Combinatorics
awd_abstract_narration:
This project involves research in the areas of analytic number theory and additive combinatorics. An important class of problems in these areas concern the distribution of prime numbers, a topic that has had important applications in theoretical computer science, cryptography, and financial security. One of the main goals of this research project is to make progress on the distributional properties of primes and other related arithmetic objects, by developing further the classical analytic tools and the more modern additive combinatorial tools, and by understanding how to effectively combine these two different tools together. It is hoped that the need for stronger results to cater for applications in analytic number theory will drive the development of additive combinatorics, and vice versa. 

More specifically, the PI will continue his work surrounding additive problems involving primes by developing and combining aforementioned analytic and combinatorial tools. The classical approaches using the theory of L-functions and sieve theory have achieved great results in this direction, and it is expected that by incorporating tools from additive combinatorics one can go beyond what the classical methods could achieve. The PI will also continue to investigate the theory of Gowers norms for multiplicative functions and for the von-Mangoldt function. These are "higher-order" extensions to classical exponential sum estimates involving these functions. The study of general Gowers norms for these functions is an essential analytic input for applying additive combinatorial tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The PI continued his research on the interface between analytic number theory and additive combinatorics while supported on this grant. Some highlights of the research carried out include:

  1. Work with Matomaki, Tao and Teravainen on Gowers uniformity of arithmetic functions in short intervals, which leads to applications in the additive theory of prime numbers. In this work, new technologies are developed to study nilsequences in additive combinatorics and to study sums over primes.
  2. Work with Bienvenu and Teravainen on a new transference principle for general systems of linear equations, and applications to almost twin primes. This work extends a famous theorem of Green and Tao.
  3. Work with Matomaki, Radziwill, Tao and Teravainen on Singmaster's conjecture in the interior of Pascal's triangle.
  4. Work with Teravainen on the Bombeiri-Vinogradov theorem for primes in nilsequences. Several applications are derived from this work.
  5. Work on an almost all version of the Balog-Szemeredi-Gowers theorem in combinatorics, including an investigation into its quantitative statement.

During the period of NSF support, the PI has supervised a PhD student, Ali Alsetri, with whom the PI has a joint paper. The PI has supervised for a period of 18 months a visiting PhD student, Mengdi Wang, who has now received their PhD. The PI has also supervised a postdoctoral researcher, Thomas Tran. In addition, the PI has supervised two undergraduates at the University of Kentucky for independent studies on the Prime Number Theorem.

During the period of NSF support, the PI has co-organized a special session on recent progress in analytic number theory in an AMS Sectional Meeting. Research during the grant period was disseminated through journal publications, and lectures by the PI in conferences and research seminars.
